column1: Phitsanulok (Thai: พิษณุโลก
column2: pronounced [pʰít.sā.nú.lôːk] listen ) is an important
column3: historic city in lower northern Thailand and is the capital of Phitsanulok Province
column4: which stretches all the way to the Laotian border. Phitsanulok is one of the oldest cities in Thailand
column5: founded over 600 years ago. It is best known as the birthplace of King Naresuan
column6: who freed the country from Burmese domination in the late 16th century
column7: and that of his brother and successor King Ekathosarot (Sanphet III). As the crossroad between the northern and central regions of the country
column8: it has long been important both for political and strategic reasons
column9: and was fought over many times in centuries past. Phitsanulok was the capital of Thailand for 25 years during the reign of King Boromma Trailokanat of Ayutthaya. On the banks of the Nan River
column10: the city was originally a small Khmer outpost known as Song Kwae
column11: before the Khwae Noi River changed its course in the 11th century CE.  Phitsanulok was also a provincial center of the Angkorian Empire during the Angkorian period. Phitsanulok is home to Naresuan University and Pibulsongkram Rajabhat University
column12: as well as to a major Royal Thai Army base.

column1: == Etymology ==
Song Khwae: The first element
column2: song
column3: means the number 'two'.  The second element

column1: Phitsanulok: The first element
column2: Phitsanu (Thai:  พิษณุ; Sanskrit: viṣṇu विष्णु "Vishnu")
column3: is a cognate of 'Vishnu'
column7: Thai:  วิษณุ).  Lack of a v sound in the Thai language accounts for the two forms. The second element
column8: lok (Thai:  โลก; Sanskrit: loka लोक 'world') means 'globe' or 'world'.  A loose translation of the entire name would be 'Vishnu's heaven'.

column1: == Geography ==
Phitsanulok is in the north of Thailand. Phitsanulok is about 377 kilometres north of Bangkok by road. Phitsanulok covers some 10
column2: 815 square kilometres
column3: or 6.4% of area in the north of Thailand and 2.1% of the area of Thailand. Phitsanulok borders on the north and the north-east of Thailand. The north is adjacent to Uttaradit and Laos. The south is adjacent to Phichit. The east is adjacent to Loei and Phetchabun. The west is adjacent to Kamphaeng Phet Province and Sukothai.

column1: Phitsanulok has many waterfalls
column2: forests and caves. In the north is central area. In the north-west is a highland. It's the important recreational area such as Kaeng Sopha waterfall
column3: Phu Hin Rong Kla and Phu Soi Dow. In the south plains along the Yom River and the Nan River is the most important agricultural district of Phitsanulok.

column1: == Climate ==
Phitsanulok has a tropical savanna climate (Köppen climate classification Aw). Winters are dry and very warm. Temperatures rise until April
column2: which is very hot with the average daily maximum at 37.4 °C (99.3 °F). The monsoon season runs from May through October
column3: with heavy rain and somewhat cooler temperatures during the day

column1: == Topography ==
Phitsanulok lies primarily on flatland with some hills.  The eastern portion of the city has some wooded area.  The city is in the Nan Basin
column2: which is part of the Chao Phraya watershed. Phitsanulok is sometimes called Song Kwae
column3: the city of two rivers
column4: a name dating to a time centuries ago when the Nan and Khwae Noi Rivers met near the city.  Today
column5: only the Nan River flows through Phitsanulok.

column1: == History ==
=== Khmer Empire ===
During the 11th century
column2: the city of Phitsanulok was only a small Khmer outpost called Song Khwae
column3: meaning two rivers. At that time
column4: the Nan and Khwae Noi Rivers both flowed through the city
column5: making it a strategic gateway to northern Thailand. The Thais were the majority in the area
column7: and would soon establish their independence and form the Kingdom of Sukhothai.

column1: === Sukhothai period ===
Phitsanulok was the major city in the east of the Sukhothai Kingdom.
Wat Aranyik and Wat Chedi Yod Thong were constructed.
=== Ayutthaya period ===
Wat Phra Sri Rattana Mahathat was constructed in 1357.
King Borommatrailokanat moved the capital of the Ayutthaya kingdom to Phitsanulok in 1463 to strengthen the northern boundary of the kingdom.
Wat Ratchaburana and Wat Nang Phaya were all built during the reign of King Borommatrailokanat.
King Borommatrailokanat's successor
column2: Boromma Ratchathirat III
column3: returned the capital of the Ayutthaya kingdom to Ayutthaya.

column2: King Naresuan the Great was born in the city.

column1: Phitsanulok was a major place of recruitment during Ayutthaya's wars with Burma.
Mother-of-pearl inlaid doors were made in 1756 for the entrance to Wat Phra Sri Rattana Mahathat at the order of King Boromakot.
After the fall of Ayutthaya to the Burmese in 1767 and the death of its last ruler
column2: a mad monk proclaimed himself king and seized control of Phitsanulok from its royal governor. King Taksin the Great was himself wounded by a musket ball during an unsuccessful attempt to capture the city from the monk. The monk later fled to the north.

column1: === 19th century ===
King Mongkut ordered the restoration of Wat Ratchaburana.
=== 20th century ===
The Phitsanulok fire of 1957 destroyed much of the older portion of the city
column2: which at the time consisted mostly of wooden buildings.

column1: On 28 November 1961
column2: the King Naresuan Shrine was completed at Chandra Palace.

column1: On 25 January 1967
column2: the Phitsanulok campus of what is now Naresuan University was established as the northern branch of the degree level College of Education. In 1974
column3: the College of Education was upgraded as Srinakharinwirot University
column4: with Phitsanulok as one of the six campuses. In 1990
column5: the regional campuses became independent universities
column6: and the Phitsanuloke campus was named after Phitsanulok-born King Naresuan the Great.

column1: Naresuan Dam was constructed from 1976 to 1985 on the Nan River as part of the Phitsanulok Irrigation Project. The dam was designed to help prevent flooding of the city.
On 8 March 1999 Phitsanulok was upgraded to city municipality (thesaban nakhon).
=== Recent events ===
In June
column3: Phitsanulok hosted the Asia-Pacific Summit of Women Mayors and Councillors.

column1: == Government ==
The chief executive of the city is the mayor.
=== Royal Thai Army ===
Phitsanulok is home to the Third Army Region of the Royal Thai Army
column2: responsible for the northern and north-western parts of the kingdom..

column1: === Media ===
The main channels for communication in the city are television and radio.  The following public television and radio stations are broadcast from Phitsanulok:
Sathaanii Witthayu Krajaisiang Thahaan Aakaat (Air Force Radio Station)
column3: in the City of Phitsanulok

column1: Witthayu Kong Phon Thahaan Raap Thii Sii (4th Infantry Division)
column3: at Fort Somdet Phra Naresuan Maharat

column1: Sathaanii Witthayu Phitaksantiraat (Communications Division
column2: Royal Thai Police)

column1: ARMY-5 (television channel 5
column2: owned and operated by the Royal Thai Army)

column1: PRD-11 (television channel 11
column2: owned and operated by the Government Public Relations Department)

column1: == Demographics ==
=== Ethnic diversity ===
The majority ethnicity in the city is Thai.  Others in the city consider themselves of Mon descent.
=== Language ===
The vast majority of residents of Phitsanulok speak central Thai.
=== Religion ===
The people of Phitsanulok are predominantly Theravada Buddhists (as are 95% of the Thai population as a whole)
column2: with a small Christian community and a few Muslim families.

column1: == Infrastructure ==
=== Educational Institutions ===
Naresuan University (abbreviated as Mor Nor for Mahawithayalai Naresuan) is an educational center of the lower northern region of Thailand. Now located in Tha Pho
column2: near the city of Phitsanulok
column3: the university was named after King Naresuan the Great
column4: and the campus features a large statue of him. Other universities and colleges in or around the city include Phitsanulok University  (private)
column6: Rajabhat Pibulsongkram University (formerly a teacher training college)
column7: and the Phitsanulok campus of the Rajamangala University of Technology Lanna.

column1: === Secondary (Mathayom) Institutions ===

Phitsanulok is home to one of the top Science and Math Secondary schools in the country. Princess Chulabhorn's College Phitsanulok (PCCPL) is a magnet boarding school that educates 750 students from lower northern Thailand that are looking to have active careers in the STEM fields.
=== Hospitals ===
There are several hospitals in the city
column2: both public and private. The province's and the city's primary public hospital is Buddhachinaraj Phitsanulok Hospital and the regional super tertiary care hospital is Naresuan University Hospital at Naresuan University
column3: Tha Pho.

column1: === Transportation ===
Phitsanulok is approximately 75 km from the Unesco World Heritage site at Sukhothai. The city can be reached by both rail and air (Phitsanulok Airport)
column2: and is on the intersection of several major highways linking the northern
column3: north-eastern
column4: and central regions of Thailand: Highway 11 (Ta Khli - Chiang Mai)
column5: Highway 12 (Mae Sot - Mukdahan) and Highway 117 (Phitsanulok - Nakhon Sawan). Highway 126 is a ring road around the city
column6: allowing through traffic to bypass the city centre.

column1: == Culture ==
Phitsanulok is home to a number of historic sculptures of the Buddha and other religious artwork including the Buddha Chinnarat
column2: the Buddha Chinnasri
column3: the Phra Sri Satsada.

column1: === Literature ===
Examples of important literary works of Phitsanulok include:
Lilit Yuan Pai (Thai:  ลิลิตยวนพ่าย
column2: English: Tale of the Fall of Lanna)

column1: Lilit Prá Lô (Thai:  ลิลิตพระลอ
column2: English: Tale of the Hero Lô)

column1: Klohng Táwâatsàmàat (Thai:  โคลงทวาทศมาส
column2: English:  Poem of the Twelve Months)

column1: Gam Sŏn Sĕe Bpràat (Thai:  กำศรวลศรีปราชญ์
column2: English:  The Legendary Wise Archer's Grip)The predominant literary language (as well as the predominant spoken language) is the central Thai dialect of the Thai language
column3: which is written in the Thai alphabet.

column1: === Sports ===
Dragon boat racing has historically been an important element of Phitsanulok culture.  In recent times
column2: football (soccer) has become increasingly popular. In 2005
column3: Phitsanulok won the 2nd Northern Youth Football Championship in the U12 and U15 age groups.Traditional Thai boxing is also a major sport in the city.

column1: == Temples ==
=== Wat Phra Sri Rattana Mahathat ===
Phitsanulok's main tourist attraction is Wat Phra Sri Rattana Mahathat
column2: known locally simply as Wat Yai (Thai: วัดใหญ่) (the big temple). This famous temple
column3: built in 1357
column4: is home to the Phra Buddha Chinnarat
column5: which is one of the most revered Buddha figures in Thailand
column6: and the official symbol of Phitsanulok Province. (An exact replica exists in the Marble Temple in Bangkok
column7: and another in Wat Saranat Thammaram in Rayong.)  The beautiful mother-of-pearl inlaid doors were built in 1756 by order of King Boromakot of Ayutthaya. The Buddha Chinnarat National Museum
column9: houses a sizeable collection of Sukhothai period art. A large provincial fair is held at the temple every January.

column1: === Other temples ===
The city is home to the following 15 active temples where Theravada Buddhism is practiced by city residents:
Wat Phra Sri Rattana Mahathat (Thai: วัดพระศรีรัตนมหาธาตุ)
Wat Ratchaburana (Thai: วัดราชบูรณะ)
Wat Aranyik (Thai: วัดอรัญญิก)
Wat Nang Phaya (Thai: วัดนางพญา)
Wat Chedi Yod Thong
Wat Tamajak (Thai: วัดธรรมจักร)
Wat Mai Opayaram (Thai: วัดใหม่อภัยาราม)
Wat Kuha Sawan (Thai: วัดคูหาสวรรค์)
Wat Nong Bua (Thai: วัดหนองบัว)
Wat Sri Wisut Tharam (Thai: วัดศรีวิสุทธาราม)
Wat Sra Gaew Pratum Thong (Thai: วัดสระแก้วปทุมทอง)
Wat Tha Maprang (Thai: วัดท่ามะปราง)
Wat Chan Tawan Tok (Thai: วัดจันทร์ตะวันตก)
Wat Chan Tawan Ook (Thai: วัดจันทร์ตะวันออก)
Wat Phan Pi (Thai: วัดพันปี)
== Other attractions ==
Sergeant-Major Dr. Thawee Buranakhet Folklore Museum: Hosts a collection of folk arts
column2: crafts
column3: basketry
column4: pottery and ancient kitchen utensils.  The museum also houses a collection of antique traps for catching snakes

column1: City walls: Unfortunately
column2: most of the older portions of Phitsanulok were destroyed in a 1955 fire. Thus little else remains of the old town besides the famous temple
column3: an ancient chedi across the road from it
column4: and a small section of the city wall. The intact portion of the ancient city wall is accessible to visitors.

column1: Buranathai Buddha Foundry: Specializes in casting bronze Buddha images.  It is the only establishment of its kind in the province.  Craftspersons specialize in the reproduction of the Phra Buddha Chinnarat Buddha image. Visitors are permitted to walk along the production line.
Nan River Houseboats: Phitsanulok is known throughout Thailand for the houseboats which still line the Nan River near Wat Phra Sri Rattana Maharat
column2: though in recent years these are becoming fewer. A houseboat museum is open to visitors.

column1: Night Market: Each evening
column2: vendors gather to form Phitsanulok's night market. Items sold include clothing and food
column3: usually at reduced prices.

column1: Chandra Palace: Chandra Palace was the birthplace of King Naresuan the Great
column2: and contains a shrine to him.

column1: Naresuan University Art and Culture Gallery: The gallery holds over 100 artistic artworks of culturally significant Thai artists.
== Festivals and events ==
Phra Buddha Chinnarat Fair: Held each January at Wat Phra Sri Rattana Mahatat Woramahawihan.
Suan Chom Nan Park Festival: Held twice a year along the Nan River.  Food and local products are on sale.
Dragon Boat Races: On the first weekend of each October
column2: dragon boat races are held outside Wat Phra Sri Rattana Mahatat Woramahawihan in the Nan River.  Each dragon boat has a crew of approximately 30 oarsmen.
